text:
My lesson. But they’re definitely going to arrest me. If it weren’t for something that happened, they would’ve done it today for sure. Maybe they’ll even arrest me today. But whatever, Sonia; they’ll let me out again. There’s no real proof against me, and there won’t be—I promise. They can’t convict me based on what they have. That’s enough. I’m just telling you so you know. I’ll figure out how to tell my mom and sister without freaking them out. My sister’s future is secure now, I think… and my mom’s should be too. That’s all. Just be careful. Will you come visit me in prison when I’m there?  
‘Oh, I will, I will.’  
They sat together, both feeling heavy and sad, like they were washed up on some deserted beach. He looked at Sonia and felt her love for him. Oddly enough, it felt like a weight. It was a weird and painful feeling! On his way to see her, he thought all his hopes rested on her. He expected to feel better, but now, with all her love directed at him, he felt way more miserable than before.  
‘Sonia,’ he said, ‘maybe you shouldn’t visit me in prison.’  
Sonia didn’t respond; she was crying. Minutes went by.  
‘Do you have a cross with you?’ she asked, as if it just hit her.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with the burden of his crime and the pain of Sonia's love, feeling increasingly isolated and unhappy despite her support.
